ARTICLE.TITLE: Kroger dropping its plan to develop on old Macy’s site at Kingsdale
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Kroger is pulling out of its plan to build a new Kroger-anchored retail center on the site of the former Macy’s store in Kingsdale Shopping Center in Upper Arlington.

The Cincinnati-based grocery chain issued a statement Friday saying it had reached the decision after studying its plans for future stores.

"Kroger continues to evaluate its brick-and-mortar capital expenditures to assess its priority in our project lineup and long-term viability. As a result, Kroger plans to develop an exit strategy for the Kingsdale site in Upper Arlington,’’ according to the statement.

"We are still growing and investing in that growth, as demonstrated by our $3.1-million investment at Kroger located at 1955 West Henderson Road, Upper Arlington, in 2019."

Kroger bought the 6.2-acre Kingsdale site for $10.5 million in January 2015, within days of Macy’s announcement that it was closing the store. Lazarus opened the store in 1970 and operated it until it became a Macy’s.

Kroger said when it bought the site that it planned to redevelop a mixed-use project on the property, but it never presented plans and the site remained empty.

Kingsdale, at Tremont Road and Northwest Boulevard, also contains a Giant Eagle Market District store.

Last month, the Columbus Landmarks preservation group named the 105,000-square-foot former Lazarus building one of its nine most-endangered buildings of 2020.

Immediately north of the former Macy’s store, a Barnes & Noble store at the point of Kingsdale is also shuttered. A phone message at the store said the store has closed and directed customers to other Barnes & Noble stores.
